I am ſent by the King, unto the moſt excellent Tomaſo, and to the reſt of the moſt faithfull Neopolitan people, to acquaint them with what great dangers we are all in, by reaſon of a ſuddain and unexpected invaſion by the French, which is like to find us in all the confuſions and diſtractions, that are able to give them the greateſt advantage, and us the moſt unavoydable ruin that can befall a Nation, deſtinated to deſtruction: Wherfore, in regard we may, perchance, want this very time, which we beſtow in words, to imploy upon more neceſſary actions, he deſires the moſt excellent Tomaſo in the firſt place: ſecondly, all his loving people, that they will open their ears to peace, and accept of all that ever he can do, or grant, in purſuance thereof; and that every man that wants arms, or ammunition, will ſpeedily repair unto
the Magazine, and there furniſh themſelves with what is wanting: then the moſt excellent, and thrice valiant Tomaſo, is deſired, by his Majeſtie, and the whole Councel, to admit of the conduct of theſe men againſt the enemy; an act of oblivion to paſſe, and all to be well.

sp.speaker: Maſſ:
sp.p: Card: What is it that the King will do?

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: What is it that you would have him do?

sp.speaker: Maſs:
sp.p: Take off all Exciſe, all, all, all, all, &c.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: It ſhall be done: I'l undertake it.

sp.speaker: Maſſ:
sp.p: And an oath never to ſet any up again.

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: Not only ſo, but I will tell you more: there ſhall be an everlaſting Monument of Marble ſet up in the Mercato, containing the articles of Agreement between the moſt excellent Tomaſo, on the one part; and the Vice-King, on the other.

sp.speaker: Maſſ:
sp.p: Now you ſay ſomething, Card: this is ſomething to the purpoſe; but there is ſomething behind, which muſt be done—or elſe, though all the French in France ſhould fly in the air, like ſo many Crows into the Land; or come by water in ſholes, like Herrings, yet will I not hear of peace, or believe a word you ſay.

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: Sir, theſe hands of mine ſhall bind them both together, but not a word of priviledges.

sp.speaker: Maſs:
sp.p: Not one word, but mum: Let the Monument be ſpeedily erected, and the Agreement ſworn unto; for Card: vve muſt have no delaies, for they are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: We will go preſently to the Vice-Roy, and have him confirm what is agreed upon: in the interim, your ſervant preſents you with this, as a little pledge of great good will, and this.
sp.stage: He preſents Maſs: with a ſuit and cloak of gold, and a chain of gold.

sp.speaker: Maſs,
sp.p:
Think you, that chains, or cloths of gold, can add? or the want of ſuch poor toyes, diminiſh from Tomaſo's worth? He's very barren of juſt merit, that borrows reſpect from the earths garbage: No, Card: I tell
thee plainly, I think my ſelf no more diſparaged by theſe cloaths, then the Sun thinks himſelf diſgrac'd by Clouds.

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: The moſt excellent Tomaſo ſpeaks admirably: I muſt confeſſe, the richeſt apparel ſets him out but meanly, who alwaies goes ſo clothed with renown, and can put on new wonders every day: But Sir, I have known thoſe, who would value pins, and rings of ruſhes, when they proceed from a heart that truly honours them: ſuch is mine: ſuch is my Preſent: ſuch may your acceptance be, and it will be the greateſt obligation wherewith I ever was obliged.

sp.speaker: Maſs:
sp.p: Well, I'l wear them for your ſake, Card: you and I muſt be better acquainted; thou art an honeſt man, and ſpeak'ſt truth, I love ſuch an one: but hark you in your ear—

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: I, I, leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Maſs:
sp.p: Come, let us go then, wy this is excellent; nothing but aſk and have: a brave World, if it will hold.

div.head: SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter Prince, with Flora in his hand, with patches on her face.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I Tell thee, ſweeteſt, envy has done thee a courteſie, to make thee look ten times lovelyer then thou didſt before. I proteſt, as it is my chiefeſt delight to look upon thee, ſo it will be my chiefeſt happineſſe to enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
Sir, as it would be an over-high preſumption in me, to believe all you ſay: ſo to ſay, I do
not believe you were in civilitie, though but to a Gentleman, but to my Prince it is rebellion: you ſay, you love me; nay, you proteſt you do, and ſwear it too; I, and that in an honourable way; 'tis a Princes word, a Princes proteſtation; 'tis a Prince that ſwears, if any thing can diſtill into my faith, the leaſt dram of beliefe out of theſe profeſſions of yours, it muſt be this; That it is as poſſible for me, Natures ruff caſt, Envies ruin, Poverties child, to appear acceptable in your eies, as it is poſſible for ſo good a Prince as you, to ſwear and vow otherwiſe then what your heart directs you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Deareſt Love, neceſſitie requires your ſpeedy aſſent; and for my love, which you ſeem ſo much to doubt of, reſt you ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
O Sir, that word, Neceſſity, is that which wounds my heart; for indeed it is neceſſity that ſends you unto me; there being as little merit in me to invite you, as love has reaſon to bring you hither. She weeps. O Sir, I beſeech you, have pity upon me, and let me not be thrown into Paradiſe over the Wall, where my entrance ſhall be my ruine; or flung into your arms, or forc'd into your bed, for then I ſhall fall no welcomer then dirt, upon your cheeks; and ſhew in your arms no otherwiſe then reeds and ruſhes, which a ſinking man is glad for to imbrace, to ſave his life. O, rather then ſo, moſt Princely Sir, I beg this favour; She kneels. I will be contented, that it may be ſo contriv'd, that to ſatisfie my Father's high ambition, it may be given out, that we are married; and ſo ordered, that there may be no doubt made thereof, untill all be ſetled: then ſhall the moſt excellent Prince chuſe him out a Wife, amongſt the race of Kings, that may be worthy of him; and bleſſe me with the happineſſe (only) of waiting upon her: for I had rather fall to my old contentment, of ſitting alone by the Sea ſhore, mending my Fathers nets; where I could
fancy the pebles to be my Subjects, and the Waves my Courtiers, then to ſit with you upon a Throne, where I am not as well ſeated by your liking, as guarded by your love.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: How prettily ſhe pleads againſt her ſelf! and how forcibly ſhe attracts honour, by flying it! Come, Flora, thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Remember your ſelf, and know who I am; I am a Fiſhers Daughter.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: A Fiſhers Daughter is no good ſound: Why did ſhe trouble my ears with it? Let me ſee; why it is impoſſible that humane nature can be ſo much above it ſelf, as is the nature of the Gods above humanitie: and yet we know, that the Gods themſelves have been ſutors unto that which we call, Woman; and if I make choyce of her, none can ſay, I have transform'd my ſelf into a Beaſt, a Bird, or into a thing that is inanimate, as have the Gods.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O, how my trembling heart expects the event of this ſole conflict!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Thus it is Reſolv'd upon the Queſtion, if you will have it ſo, Neceſſity ſhall marry the Fiſhers Daughter: but I'l have thee; thee, not by conſtraint, but by affection; not by compulſion, but by free choyce; not to be the Jone make-peace of our Land, but as one who beſt deſerves my love, and merits me.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Can there be a diſtinction then, between me, and the Fiſhers Daughter?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Yes, Flora, ſuch a one as the Sun makes between a vapour and an exhalation; which being one and the ſame thing, whil'ſt it cleaves unto the earth, is but a fog: but being exhal'd and drawn up nearer towards the Sun, it appears as glorious as it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Great Prince, whoſe laſting fame is ſuch, that flatteries can neither hurt, nor hyperboles reach, if I were good at either: with what faces will the honourable Women look, when they ſhall ſee ſuch a one as I, as your Bride, delivered into holy hands, to be made yours?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: With ſuch like faces of wonder and amazement, as the houſhold Gods did look, when mortals were exalted above their nature, and had their conſtellations in the higheſt Firmament, glob'd by the breaths of all the Gods, whil'ſt they were tied to reſidence in tabernacles made with hands, and yet durſt neither envy nor complain.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Sir, You ſpeak ſuch high language, that I am afraid you exerciſe Rhetorick, rather then Love.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I here engage my honour, as deeply, as the moſt unfeigned heart can direct a tongue how to oblige it, that I rather want language to expreſſe my love, then am either vain, or diſſembling, in any thing of all which I profeſſe.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, I can anſwer you no more, but in this language— weeps —Speak, ſpeak apace, my beſt Oratours; ſpeak out and tell him the news from whence you're come; hee's good, and may, perchance, give credit—

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Hold up, celeſtiall ſhowers, you'l drown a little World: the precious diſtillations are in value next to penitentiall tears, wherewith the gods oft drink themſelves to ſuch a height of kindneſſe, that they forget that they are juſt—Weep upon my boſome, and make the ſoyl fruitfull in the increaſe of that, vvhich thine ovvn iuſt merit hath there ſovvn vvith a full hand: What! doth ſhee ſink under the burthen of her She ſounds.
owne joyes, Flora, my Flora, cannot my voyce recall thee ſooner then waters, my affections are above their heate Flora, my deareſt, dear Flora, where haſt thou been? what doſt thou meane to do?
sp.stage: She comes to her ſelfe and finds her armes about his necke.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Sir you may ſee my ſenſes were all fled, when mine armes preſumed to imbrace that Sun it ſhould adore, they are of too baſe mettall to make a chaine for that necke.

sp.speaker: Prin:
sp.p: Object that fond objection no more (I charge you) I conſider thee now as thy fathers daughter, as thy Fathers Daughter now, I ſay; who at this time ſtands the abſoluteſt of Monarchs, and commands all, me, Kings, and Vice-Kings, and the greateſt Princes, nor doe I think otherwiſe then that the Fates prodigiouſly rais'd him up to this greatneſſe to make thee my equall, I am not a Secretary of their State, nor privy Councellour to their wills, but whatſoever their Decrees are, I take it ſo, and ſo take thee.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p:
Well then, I'le tell you what I will doe for you, I will bee faithfull to you, I will never offend you, I will alwayes love you, when I am with you, I will bee a ſervant ready to obſerve and put in execution all your deſires, and when I am out of your ſight, whereſoever I am, I wil ſpend my time in ſtudying how I may next pleaſe you when I come into your preſence: when you ride from home, I will get up upon the wings of prayer, and will importune Heaven that no bad influence from their Stars may hurt you: I will ſo charme the earth with the often falling of my tears, that no noiſome vapor ſhall ariſe to prejudice my love, and when you go into the wars I will have fervency enough in prayer (lawfully) to make you ſhotfree. When my Love ſhall charge his enemies the
mouthes of their Guns ſhall loſe their voices, and their bullets when they come near my Lord, ſhall forget their meſſage, Ile ſo prevail with—

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Away, Away, thou little fool, thou: tis the prerieſt little fond thing that ever I ſaw, what doſt thou doe, nothing but weep, ſhe weeps: Ile d • y up your rears for you: Come, he kiſſes her. Will that doe it? the earneſt of my hearts union: the ſeale of all that ever I have ſaid or promiſed; the aſſurance of what we are now going about, without more delayes.
Let each man envy, what the gods ſhall praiſe.

div.head: SCENA II.
div.stage: Enter Vice Roy, Card. Prince, &c.

sp.speaker: Vice Roy.
sp.p: How do you like your Miſtris, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Vice Roy
sp.p: Not very well I beleeve.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Yes very well.

sp.speaker: Vice Roy.
sp.p: Truly?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Truly I doe.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: You are not taken with her?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: So much taken with her, that Ile take her, and bleſſe the fates which threw me headlong into ſo great happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Vice Roy.
sp.p: The boye's in love upon my life.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Sir, Ile tell you, I went unto her as if it had been ſome miſerable Ward forc▪d by his Tyrant Guardian to a peece of ſome deformity, and to be ſacrificed to ſome ſoul beaſt, to preſerve a faire eſtate; but when I came into her preſence, I found the world could not parallel her for beauty, when I c • nvers'd with her; I ſaw ſhe was matchleſſe for wit, behaviour, language, or any thing, that
might compleat or adorne the moſt accompliſhed of all her ſex: nor ſhall all the riches in the world invite me for to ſeek another Miſtris; rather then the meaneſſe of her condition, ſhould be thought a conſideration why I ſhould not have her, I would deſcend to her capacity and tu • n fiſherman. Nor lyes it in the power of art or force of argument to wean me from her.

sp.speaker: Vice Roy.
sp.p: Good Son, we are all glad ſhe likes you ſo wel, we were all afraid we ſhould be faine to uſe both art and argument, to draw on your affections. But Indeed I have heard many commend her for a pretty girle.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, Maſſenello is comming towards the Pallace.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: I'le goe and bring him in.

sp.speaker: Vice Roy.
sp.p: By all means. Son, remember you aske y • ur father bleſſing when he comes in.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall aske him for a bleſſing, and the greateſt bleſſing: that any man alive can give me.
sp.stage: Enter Maſſenello taking the right hand of the Card. all in gold. Attendants.

sp.speaker: V. Roy,
sp.p: Tomaſo is welcome to us very oppor • unely, for my ſonne was (even) upon your entrance in a high encomion of your daughter: truly in a word hee's over head and ears in love with her, and I am glad to ſee it.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Vice Roy, you have reaſon for what you ſay: and I hope there is no love loſt; my daughter loves him as well, and though I ſay it, ſhe is a match for the beſt Prince in Europe.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: I make no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: But I have not heard your Son ſpeake, yet, concerning her, let me hear how you like her from your own month.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Sir, I like her as a new come ſoule likes Elyſium, and with the ſame affection that the moſt ambitious man likes ſitting in a throne crown'd with his owne hearts deſires.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Why then young man thou'rt happy, when will you marry her?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: When will the hunger-ſtarv'd wretch eat meat? or the thirſty ſoule quench his flames? or the man that is a cold come near the fire; but as ſoon as ere he can.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Why then to morrow is the day, how ſayes the Vice King.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: With all my heart, the ſooner, the better.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Come then we will to the Archive ſcovato, and there you both ſhall ſolemnly ſweare before the high Alter to performe all the Articles which are agreed upon between you both, in the behalfe of the new made happier Neopolitans, and by this the Monument contayning the articles agreed upon, is erected in the Mercato, and from the Cathedrall, the Cavalcato in the greateſt pompe, ſhall bring you both as paires coupled in the ſame deſires of procuring your Countries good, and there before all the people, you ſhall conſecrate the Monument with your preſence; and let them all ſee how in your peaceable intentions you both meet in parrallels like Apollo's twins, and from thence unto the performance of thoſe nuptiall rates which ſhall make the peace between you everlaſting.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: The Card. is a good man, he ſpeaks well, but when ſhall this be done, Card.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Come one thing firſt, another at the heels,
When all's concluded action runs on wheels.

div.head: SCENA III.
div.stage: Enter people running over the Stage after French men, they take one.
div.p: 1. HAh Mounſier, have we taken you, off with his head.

sp.speaker: Mounſ.
sp.p: O pardon a moy ie vous ſom pric.
2. Mounſier don't be afraid, we won't hurt your locks, wee'l onely cut off your head.

sp.speaker: Mounſ.
sp.p: Vat have I done to you Gentilmen, mort dien?
3 Take heed of his Miſtris favours there.
sp.stage: Enter people with two more for French-men, but one of them is an Engliſh-man.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: More ſacks to the Mill, here's a couple of Mounſiers more, they are cutting off, I know not how many Mounſ. heads every where.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: Swounds, I am an Engliſh-man, Engliſh man, Engliſh man, Engleterra, Engleterra.
2. He cries Engleterra, Engleterra, and the Rogue ſpeaks French.
3. You don't know, it may be Engliſh for ought you know.
1. A pox confound him, he's a French-man, you may know him by his points hanging at the wrong end of his breeches.
2. Away with him then, off with it, off with it, cut off his head, let it be cut off, though there were no more heads in England.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p:
Damn me, and ram me, and ſinke me, I am an Engliſh-man; what a devill doe you meane to dee with me, I am an Engliſh man, I tell you, what won't you
beleeve a body when a body tells you the right: Sounds I am an Engliſh-man; hell confound you all for a company of Arſe-wormes, Turky-drivers, and Goat mongers; what a devill would you have? won't you beleeve a body with a pox?
3. Piſh, piſh, you may ſee he is a French-man by his locks and favours, and by his garniſhed cotpeece.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Away with him, away him, cut off his head.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: What a pox are you, are all ſtarke mad? is there never a wiſe man amongſt you, that underſtands Engliſh.
sp.stage: They uſe violence to him, he raves.
sp.p: A plague confound you all, a devills dogs couples, hags and furies light upon you, for a company of hog dogs, and cow-dogs, and vinegar-bottles.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: If he will not be ordered, hold up his head, and cut his throat.
sp.stage: They hold him by the nape of the neck, he ſpits in their face like a Cat, at laſt cryes Boh, and frights them; in which interim, comes two Engliſh Merchants by and ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Hold Gentlemen, hold I pray you, he is an Engliſh-man, we know him.
3. You came in a very good time, or elſe you had ſound your Country-man ſhorter by the head.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: Shorter by the head ke they? hearlikins; I was never in ſuch a feare in all my life: a pox on them for a company of block-heads, they could not underſtand ſenſe, nor heare reaſon; a company of cuckoldly curs, take my head off: 'Tis more then they could do, or elſe it had not been on now.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: You are well enough ſerv'd, you muſt be in the French-faſhion forſooth, with your all a mode de France, with your locks, favours, and • ibbans.
sp.stage: He cuts them off, and throws them away.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: Got by it: nay what had I like to have loſt by it? for I am ſure I had like to have loſt my head by it which is more then ever I ſhould have got by them as long as I had liv'd; but if they ever find me with your all a mode, de France, as you call it, I'le give them leave, not onely to cut off my head, but to make a devill of me when they have done, pray change cloaks, and hats with me.
sp.stage: The Merchants charge cloaths with him, and were likely to loſe their heads by the miſtate.
Enter a Citizen with a French mans head in one hand, and his faulchion in t'other.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: Doe you heare friend; what's the price of your Cods-head?

sp.speaker: Cit
sp.p: You ſee what it is, 'tis a French mans head.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: I pray let me have it, I will give thee mony for it.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What mony will you give me?

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: What mony will you aske?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: A French Crowne.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: What ſhall I crowne him now his head's off, hee'l be little the better for that.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You ſhall have it for halfe a Crowne.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: What ſhall I give thee for that ſword?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yours.

sp.speaker: Engliſh.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt, for this is an all a mode de France too, I'le endure um no more.
sp.stage: He changes his brave Sword for a ruſty Semiter, paſſes two French-men over the Stage, and taking the Engliſh-man for an Italian, are in great fear.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Fee fo fum, hoh what are you French men?
1. French, Mercy, Mercy, Mercy, Mercy: Making pittifull faces.
sp.stage: He kneeles, and the Engliſh man layes his ſword over the firſt French mans head and ſays,
sp.p: Eng. Riſe up Sir Chriſtopher Boon-grace.
2 French, A Sir, you be de good Engliſhman, mee can ſpreake little Engliſh, me have been one, two, three times in London, ſpare you me I pre.
sp.stage: Hec takes him up by the chinne.
sp.p: Engliſh, Come thou ſhalt ſee London the fourth time You muſt not bee ſo fearefull, had I been ſo tame as you, whereas now I am a cutter off of heads, I might have caried mine own head thus.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: Who have you there?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: They are Engliſh Gentleman of my acquaintance.
sp.stage: Exeunt omnes, French hugging the Engliſh.

div.head: SCENA. IV.
div.stage: Enter a guard with attendants, V. Roy. Maſſ: On his right hand the Card: on his left hand under the ſame Canopie into the Mereato a monument of counterfeit marble, with articles inſcribed behind a curtaine, The Curtaine drawn Trumpets ſound,

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: BEhold the hierogliphiks of our peace and happines, the landskipp of a joyful Country, the Map of a world of good that is derived unto us by this days happineſſe, a monument which gives the beſt characters of the moſt wiſe King, and the moſt invincible Tomaſo, here is the originall, peruſe it and ſee if they agree not.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: They agree to a word.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Tis well, but is't not pitty that the winde ſhould blow upon it? or that the rayne ſhould fall upon ſo faire a peece? or that the Sun ſhould fade any of its coulours? or that bold and forward hands ſhould ſully any of its precious ſtones? or that time it ſelfe, ſhould eate, this, with the reſt of things?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Moſt excellent Sir, I have given directions for a ſafeguard of Iron, whoſe bars ſhall be ſo high and ſharpe, that not any ſhal be able to behold it, otherwiſe then at their due diſtance.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: But Card: have you made any proviſion againſt Winde and Weather? that time it ſelfe may never fill her paunch with ſuch bits, as are too great dainties for ſuch a common feeder.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: What the moſt excellent Tomaſo ſhall think further fit to the preſervation of that which preſerves ſo great fame, wee ſhall bee glad admirers of, but for my owne particular, I have given no further directions concerning it.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Then I ſhall, where's Sig. Burlameo.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: It was nobly reſolved on.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Burlameo I will have thee poſt to Egypt (hah doeſt thou ſtare upon me?) and there take patterne of the biggeſt Piramis that's there, and make me a ſhelter over this monument fifty cubits higher than the higheſt of all Egypts Piramides, and that ſhall be a Penthouſe to keep it from the rain, ſo that that greedigut Time ſhal find it the hardeſt bone to picke, that to feed upon it, it ſhall looſen the old teeth of aged time, that they ſhall drop out faſter than theſe ſtones ſhall fall, and at laſt finde it meate of ſo hard digeſtion that time it ſelf ſhall take ſo great a ſurfeit that it ſhall ceaſe to be.
And dying yeeld unto eternity.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ah Maſſenello, ah Maſſenello, ah Maſſenello.

sp.speaker: Card
sp.p: This is enough to make him ſtarke mad, lets follow h • s humour.

sp.speaker: Burla.
sp.p: S • I heare you, and having taken meaſure of your mind, Il • f •• i • to a haire,

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: When the d • vill's blinde, your reſolutions are like your ſelfe, great and glorious.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: This age is happy that hath produc'd a man fit for ſo high and mighty undertakings.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Now nothing's left undone, but that which muſt be done, the marriage.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.l: That ſhall be don, to morrow is the day.
That Hymeneus askes us leave to play.

div.head: SCENA: V.
div.stage: Enter Vrſula and Bonella.

sp.speaker: Vrſula,
sp.p: Is the Pothecary comming? prethee go and fetch him to me, and ſtay you without.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.p: I'le fetch him preſently Madam,

sp.speaker: Vrſ
sp.p: My Mothers death I will revenge on her who was the cauſe of it, b • ſides ten thouſand hazards I will run, before Ile ſuffer her to prince it over me, that face which age could neither blemiſh nor years decay ſhall looke as pale as death can make it. I'd rather dye my ſelfe then ſhe ſhould live to be ſo much above me, and thought worthy of ſo high eſtate whilſt I neglected, ſtand like a forelorne hope periſhing for want of ſeconds, and why? becauſe I am blacke and ſhee's faire, marry muff: I thinke my penny as good as her's.
sp.l: Pepper is blaeke and hath a good ſmacke,
And every man will it buy:
When Snow it is white, and lies in the dike
And every man let's it lye.
sp.p: Honeſt Pothecary I ſent for thee to doe me a pleaſure, I am ſo troubled with Rats in my chamber that I cannot be quiet for them, I pray thee teach me a way how I may deſtroy them.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.p: Madam I will fetch you ſome Rats-baine immediately.

sp.speaker: Vrſu.
sp.p: No, no, That's but a ſcurvy weak poyſon, they'l take it and live ſo long after it, that they'le creep hehind the Wainſcot and get into holes, and there lye and ſtinke, able to poiſon any living ſoule, I would have a quick diſpatching poyſon that ſhall worke preſently upon them that they ſhall not ſtir from the place.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.p: Mad: I warrant you, Ile fetch you ſuch a poyſon as ſhall do the feate.

sp.speaker: Vrſula
sp.p: Why well ſaid honeſt fellow: here's for thy paines.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.p: I thanke you Maddam, I never was ſo rewarded for killing of Rats, I pray God ſhee puts it to no worſe uſe, but why ſhould I ſuſpect any thing, ſhee payes mee liberally.
sp.stage: Enter Prince with Flora in his hand.

sp.speaker: Flora,
sp.p: My Lord, though I am not worthy to indent with you, or ingage you to the leaſt promiſe, yet I may be in capacity of begging a favour at your hands:

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: What is it? and command what lyes within my power.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Here is my only ſiſter, pleaſe you to take notice of her, and let her bee within your thoughts to make her happy.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: As happy ſhall ſhee bee as induſtry it ſelfe can find out wayes to make her ſo-

sp.speaker: Vrſula.
sp.p:
I thanke you Sir: I pray Siſter keepe your happineſſe
to your ſelfe, I doe not deſire to be made happy by you.
She flings out of the roome, and takes the Pot. with her, remains in occulto.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What an unmannerly ſiſter is this of thine.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Sir, It may be ſhe cannot brook this happineſſe, wherewith you'r pleas'd to crowne me, and the more I ſeek to pleaſe her, the worſe ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: She's angry that ſhe's ſo blacke, and thou ſo faire.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Not ſo my Lord, but it may be ſhe is angry that a Prince of ſo great judgement ſhould be ſo much deceived in his choice, as is able to verefie the proverb how that love is blinde.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: That love is blinde indeed that doth not ſee
Cauſes ſufficient for loving thee.
Love is not blinde becauſe he hath no eyes,
But cauſe he's guided by loves ſympath • es.
Love ſees, and ſeeing loves but yet in part;
But he loves throughly that doth love by heart.
sp.p: But I'le tell thee my deareſt dear, thy ſiſter is mad that I am not a Sutor unto her, and I had as live be a Sutor unto the ſhades of night, and imbrace a moon-calfe as to be l • nckt to ſuch deformity.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Not ſo an't pleaſe your highneſſe, ſhades ofttinies are ſought for, when the brighteſt Sun-beames are eſchewed; and though a black one pleaſe not you, ſhe may be pleaſing in anothers eye.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Come, come, I know and ſee her conditions to be as foule as is her viſage, which is the index of her minde; 'tis thy goodneſſe to ſay otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well Sir, I that am ſo happy in your affections, have the leſſe reaſon to be troubled at your diſ-affection to any elſe but indeed I muſt intreat you to love my ſiſter, though.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Well then, to morrow when ſhe is my ſiſter, I'le begin to love her, becauſe ſhe is my ſiſter, though there be as much difference between thee and her, as between night and day.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Now your highneſſe is pleas'd to ſpeake of nights and dayes, when I thinke how that there is no day to come, onely one night to paſſe, before you make me beleeve, I ſhall be your wife; my joyes begin to be orewhelm'd with feares, and ſadneſſe takes poſſeſſion of my heart, and outs thoſe wonted lively apprehenſions of the happineſſe I heretofore conceived of being yours: ſurely my heart hath onely room for you to caſt anchor there, and ſo poſſeſſe me of ſome hope, but not to bring the Sovereigne of a Sea of bliſſe, laden with the riches of your love into ſo poor a harbour.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Humility is the crowne of all other vertues, and thou crowneſt humility, with ſuch a becomingneſſe, that ſhee is true humility no where but in thee; and it deſerves an exaltation, which it ſhall ſoon finde.

sp.speaker: Urſula.
sp.l: O how I burn to be reveng'd: my malice (it is true)
Was firſt to one; now, in tha • one, to two.

div.head: SCENA I.
div.p: Maſſenello ſteals in the night time unto his Monument to adore it, clad in his night Gow • e.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p:
THus in the night of ſecreſie have I ſtolne time from ſleep, that I might ſacrifice with uncontrolled devotion, unto the Idea of my minde [He adores it.] Tis a faire peece. They were fools who thought to make Babels Tower reach heaven by building of it high. Approaches made to heaven, doe
not conſiſt in degrees of height, nor are ſteps, and rounds of ſtaires, and ladders wayes to climbe up thither, heaven is every where where men, God-like behave themſelves.
sp.l: Fools were all the Wiſemen ſeven;
This is it that reaches heaven.
sp.p: Come wee'l be thought men no more; I begin to be immortall the ſymptomes of mortallity begin to leave me, ſleep: that dull and ſenceleſſe block-head, begins to know his diſtance; and to thinke himſelfe no fit companion for us, hunger and thirſt, begin to ſtand aloofe, and not to ruſh ſo boldly into our preſence as they were wont. I will ſhake off them too, and then mortallity good night.

Alexander was an Aſſe, he would be deified, but never deſerv'd it: he went with an Army of drunken Grecians, and ſo ſtumbled upon a victory; but did he overcome a warlike Nation with a company of boyes and canes? did he frighten a company of daring Spaniards into their retreat, and ruin with the ruffling of a company of blew aprons? he that will become a Deity, muſt not reſt himſelfe contented with the attributes of High and Mighty, but he muſt be wonderfull: And now I think on • , I will goe and bethinke my ſelfe (how I may teach the people how to flye, that things call'd walls, and towers, flanckers, and counter-ſcarfes, palliſadoes, and ſtockadoes, fitter to keep hogs and dogs from entrance, then men indued with ſo rare a thing as is a ſoule, ſurely this invention was leſt for me to bring into the world; I'le make them as good keep out the wind, the light, the common ayre, as keep out me; and ſo I'le conquer all the world, and not like foole Alexander, lye downe and cry, becauſe there be no more worlds to conquer. I'le goe and be merry with the gods, drinke their wine, ſing catches with the angells, hunt the Devill, run races with the horſes of the Sun, hob-naile my ſhoos with a couple of old Moons, and ſo drinke a pot at every one of the celeſtiall
ſignes. It is decreed, nor ſhall thy fort, O Rome reſiſt my vow.

div.head: SCENA II.
div.stage: Enter Mariamma and Urſula, Mar. ſets downe a cawdle, and Urſula ſteals an opportunity to drop her poyſon into it, Mariam. calls her grandchild Flora.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: DAughter, the Prince hath ſent you word that he is comming to fetch you to Church, eat this before you go, becauſe ſtate nuptiall ceremonies are very tedious.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Grandmother, I humbly thanke you: but I am ſo ſtrait lac'd that I cannot get any thing down.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, come, you ſhall; there's a fine trick indeed, you may chance wiſh you had.

sp.speaker: Urſula.
sp.p: I, and repent it too, I'le aſſure you.
sp.stage: She takes, and eats part of it.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I doe not like it: there is ſomething in it, that hath not a good taſte—O I begin to feel it work, Grandmother I'm poiſoned.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How poyſon • d? nay child I'le aſſure you there's nothing in't but what is good; for I am ſure I put all the ingredien • s in't my ſelfe: you ſhall ſee me eat of it.

sp.speaker: Urſula.
sp.p: Mother don't, you don't know what may be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Don't: I'm ſure there▪s nothing in't but good.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O my ſenſes begin to fail me, and this poyſonous drug begins to worke upon my vitalls.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Curſed caitiffe, what haſt thou done, poyſoned thy Grandmother and thy ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Urſula.
sp.p: I told you that you ſhould not eat of it, and yet you would.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why then thou confeſſeſt the murther.

sp.speaker: Urſula.
sp.p: I doe, but not of you, you might have chus'd, now let us ſee in what fine pompe ſhe'l go unto her wedding.

sp.speaker: Mariam.
sp.p: Here's the murthereſſe lay hold on her.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poyſoned, and I too by that infernall hag.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Furies light upon her, O my dear Flora, run, and without there is a Padua Doctor, bid him come hither quickly, quickly, quickly. O my deare Flora, ſhe breaths, ſhe's alive, ſhe's warme. O helpe, helpe, helpe, for the Lords ſake.

div.stage: Enter Doctor.
div.p: Now Doctor ſhew your skill, and be renown'd for evermore.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Sir, I have an antidote that if it hath not too much wrought upon the vitals, it will recover her; however, it will fetch her to her ſenſes againe for a while.

div.stage: He puts it into her mouth.
div.p: So it will diſſolve of it ſelfe, hold her up.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: She begins to looke up already.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Doſt thou know me? O I will puniſh that black devill with a hundred tortures.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
No my dear Lord, let not my ſiſter be put unto any tortures for my ſake; for I forgive her with all my heart, and thanke God that he hath given me ſo much ſenſe before I dye, as to make it my laſt requeſt to you, that you would do ſo too. I was once entring into the fineſt place that ever was ſeen; ſuch fine flowers, ſuch rare muſicke, ſuch glorious creatures! and the door was open
for me, and all, and my thought ſome body pull'd me back and told me that one would ſpeak withme? was it you.

sp.speaker: Prince;
sp.p: Deare heart it was I, would you not willingly if it lay in your power, forbeare that place a while for my ſake?

sp.speaker: Flora
sp.p: Though you are the fineſt man in the world, yet you are not ſo fine as any there, but I pray don't you doe any thing to my Siſter, don't diſgrace her.

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: She hath poiſoned her Grandmother too, here ſhe lyes.

sp.speaker: Flora;
sp.p: I am ſorry for it, why would you uſe ſo much diligence to recall me, and extend no charity to her.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Sir, it doth her hurt to talke ſo much, a little ſleep will doe her good, if any thing, and gentle muſicke would be requiſite if it may be had;

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: Yes, call for the muſick that was appointed for our nuptiall feaſt, and let them change their note, to ſad Eligies. Carry that Cerberus bitch out of my ſight, and let her be cut into a thouſand peeces, and caſt to dogges.

sp.speaker: Vrſula,
sp.l: I ſtand your fury, ſwell untill thou burſt,
I am beforehand with you, do your worſt.
sp.stage: Muſicke plays, A ſong. ſhe ſleeps, he weeps,
sp.l: O Yee Gentle powers above,

l.hi: What are you your ſelves but love?
Helpe us, helpe us more or leſſe;
And we'l ſing you, your due praiſe;
If not yeares, yet give us dayes.
If you will not grant theſe things,
Doe but give my ſpirit wings.
And ſee how glad my ſoule within
Will be to leape out of her skin
In life or death I care not whither;
So we two may be together.
If I ha'nt deſerv'd ſuch grace,
Give me leave to buy a place,
To be where ſhe'le be by your doome,
I'le give a Kingdome for a roome.
Crown and Scepter, Throne and Ball
Let me have her, and take all.

sp.speaker: Flora
sp.p: O Sir I muſt bid you farewell,

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: Stay a little my deareſt Flora, I will marry thee in ſpight of death, that when I meet thee in another world I may claime thee as one that was ſometimes mine. Prieſt do your office: ſtay a while, go fetch the murdereſſe, that I may doe it in ſpight of envy.

sp.speaker: Servingman,
sp.p: Sir ſhe is dead.

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: Bring her in dead.

sp.speaker: Serving.
sp.p: Sir She is cut in peeces.

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: Bring in the peeces.

sp.speaker: Servirg.
sp.p: Sir they were throwne to the dogges, and the dogs have eaten them.

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: Let me have the dogs brought in, for by all thats ſacred.—Flora makes ſignes to ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Sir ſhe would ſpeake with you, ſhe feels her ſelf departing.

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: What would my deareſt have with me.

sp.speaker: Flora,
sp.p: O Sir, I feele my ſelfe now going to the place from whence you called me backe, doe ſo no more for charity ſake, I gladly would have lived yours I muſt confeſſe, but I am happier in this, that it thus lies in my power to expreſſe a fitter tribute of my love to you, rather thus to die your Martyr, then to live your wife, like Icarus I fly'd,
And ſoard too high, fell downe and di'd.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Where are theſe fooles that will, and won't bee married: why don't ye come away, they all ſtay for you?

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: O Sir, your devill daughter hath forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: What's here to doe, my mother and my daughter dead? who durſt do this? that death himſelfe (had I forbid him) durſt not do it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Your owne daughter, poiſoned your own mother, and her owne Siſter.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Where is ſhe, ſhe ſhall have juſtice.

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: That is done already.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: How, juſtice done already, are you turn'd juſticiary? I thought there had been no more Juſtices but my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: I thought according to the Articles of our agreement, you were to become a private man, and to have nothing to do with juſtice buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Maſs.
sp.p: I tell thee thou Prince of Darkeneſſe, I am immortall.

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: I will not diſpute with you in that argument, only give me leave to take away this relique, that I may pay the tribute of mine eyes thereto, and performe the laſt kind office of a lover, in ſeeing her honourably interred.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Why didſt thou love her truly? wouldeſt thou have been married to her?

sp.speaker: Prince,
sp.p: Would you be wedded to your wil.—

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Nay, if thou loveſt her but halfe ſo well, take her and much good do thee with her.
sp.stage: Exeunt omnes with the Corps. Manet Maſſ.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p:
My mother dead, my wife dead, my daughter dead, al dead? why now I ſtand by my ſelf like the popular ſtar, fixt in his ſeate, and all the heavens of great and little ones do move about me. Me thinks that preſumptuous boy began to talke of articles, doe they thinke that Ile be confin'd to articles, the ſun may be confin'd within its tropickes, the
Sea may be confin'd within its bounds, the earth may be confin'd in a circle: but Tomaſo, cannot, will not bee confin'd: Ile therefore goe, and preſently confound, that preſumptuous monument that dares confine Tomaſo within any tearmes, had it root fixt in the very center, I would pluck it up: or did the articke and antarticke poles, ſtrike through it as ſtayes to hold it up, I'de caſt it downe, I'le have my words law, my will reaſon, my pleaſures obſerved, and my commands obeyed, I do not like this hoc nihil indeclinabile, i'de have ut ſunt Divorum, Mars, Baccus, Apollo, Virorum, O I love to be like one of theſe thundring gods, I'le tell you what, I'le begin a new world, and if men wo'nt follow me it is no matter, it is but to teach foxes how to ſpeake, they have cunning and ſubtlety enough, Lyons have ſtrength, and valour, horſes courage, dogs diligence, and faithfullneſſe. It is but teaching theſe the uſe of reaſon, and we will bid defiance to all mankind: and what is this to one that is immortal: but firſt I muſt down with this confining monument. I go about it.

div.head: SCENA III.
div.stage: Enter V: Roy: Pr: Card: Cap: of the Caſtle, Mat: Lo: Cha • : Lo: Con: &c.

sp.speaker: V: Roy:
sp.p: WEE are all reſolved to honor that faire body parted from as faire a ſoule, with as great ſolemnity as if ſhee were my owne daughter, or my owne ſonnes wife.

sp.speaker: Pr:
sp.p: O Sir, the honour of thoſe rich jewells which were ingaged within this breaſt that's now turned to earth; cannot be let downe, or an inventory taken of halfe the good • ſhe had there laid up in ſtore, were all men in the worl • regiſters, the world paper, and the Ocean incke, The pens would ſcrawle the paper, and the paper drink That Inckie Ocean up: the worke unfiniſh'd lye: And a thouſand pities call for new ſupply.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: We all contribute ſorrow to your ſufferings, and pray we may not ſuffer too much with you.

sp.speaker: V. Roy:
sp.p: Goe know the reaſon of this noyſe, Exit. Lo. Con. I pray that all be well, the fellow was mad enough before, and it may be this will make him ten times worſe.

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: I 'tis no matter, and if he be; if • he people be not all mad.
sp.stage: Enter Lo. Con. with Bakers, Brewers, Butchers, &c.

sp.speaker: Lo. Con.
sp.p: I have brought you a great many of diſcontented people, who ſeem to be as much diſpleaſed with the times as we; I thinke we ſhall be very good company together.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: Friends ſpeake your mindes freely, we give you leave.

sp.speaker: Bakers.
sp.p: Then Sir know; this Tomaſo is mad: ſtark mad: he runs up and downe the ſtreets, ſtriking every man, that comes in his way; has thrown downe the Articles, will ſtand to nothing, breeds confuſion, and turnes all topſie turvy.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: This is the Idoll which ye firſt ſet up, and then ador'd, now ye know the difference, betwixt a golden Scepter, and an iron rod.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: I but a pox confound him, he made us beleeve ſuch ſtrange ſtories, and we ſee n • thing performed, wherefore we are come unto you in the behalfe of the reſt of our fellow Citizens to make our grievance knowne, and to crave your aſſiſtance for our redreſſe.

sp.speaker: V Roy.
sp.p: Alas how can I helpe you!

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: Nay Sir, we'l helpe you: and our ſelves too, and you'l but give us leave.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p:
My Maſters, it was your own fault that brought you to this, and it muſt be your owne vertue to bring y • u
out of it againe; he is of your owne making, and now you would faine be rid of him if you knew how.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: Yes we know how to be rid of him, and you'l give us leave.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: How.

sp.speaker: Bakers.
sp.p: Wee'l ſerve him as he ſerv'd us.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: No, as he ſerv'd us.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, Ha, He.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: About it then if you have the hearts.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: I tell you Sir he is as dead already to my thinking as a doore nayle.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: In the interim by all means let the Secretary be ſent for, as about ſome earneſt buſineſſe, leſt he prevent the plot, and when 'ti done, that we may be ſure of him.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: My Lord, I pray will you take the pains.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: This is that which I was ſpeaking unto you of, we muſt lay hold upon the preſent diſguſt of the people, and make it ſerve our turnes, theſe joyned together with the Morcato men, will make a good luſty party.

sp.speaker: Lo. Con.
sp.p: Here is the Secretary, I met him comming to your Highneſſe.

sp.speaker: V Roy.
sp.p: What is your pleaſure Mr. Secretary?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Sir I am ſent unto you in the behalfe of the people, who heare how that there is a great reſort of Citizens unto the Caſtle, and thoſe m • n of no good report.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: And what then? what of that? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: They would know their buſineſſe, and would not have you thus to countenance them; and further, they would have you leave the Caſtle, and remaine with them for their ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: What people is that which you are come from? they were people that were here, and of more loyalty and underſtanding then the people that have ſent you hither. Your Maſter's mad already, and you are little better.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Well Card. ere it be long you ſhall think your ſelfe the maddeſt of the three.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: This villain muſt not goe alive out of the Caſtle, if he doe, hee'l ſpoyle the plot and us.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire your ſpeedy anſwer.

sp.speaker: V. Roy.
sp.p: Our anſwer is your diſmiſſion; you may be gone.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Thou ſawcie peece of inſolence, dareſt thou conteſt with Majeſty, be gone.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I go—but—remember this

sp.speaker: Card:
sp.p: Let the fool go, hee'l be met with, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Capt:
sp.p: Doe ye knew the man?

sp.speaker: Guard:
sp.p: Yes, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: That's he.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Open the gate there, let downe the bridge.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: What are you? I will not open the gate, I have no order for it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Well you ſhall rue it ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Doe you threaten the Kings guard? take that:

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: O I am kill'd.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: It makes no matter, you ſhould have a better tongue in your head then.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: 'Twas not my tongue that made me thus depart,
But 'twas this vile, and baſe, and treacherous heart.

div.head: SCENA IV.
div.stage: Enter Maſſ. into the Mercato looking wildly; all the people about him, after a long pauſe, he ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p:
WOnders! wonders! without all bounds and meaſures. Death and Cupid quartered together laſt night in the ſame room: Venus call'd up her boy betimes, time call'd death, preſent employment was for both: the more haſte, the worſe ſpeed: death groping for his quiver in the morning, laid his hand upon Cupids, and h • s eyes being out of his head, takes the boyes quiver for his owne: Cupid as blinde as he, took the deadly quiver in his hand, and dreſſing himſelfe in the morning, in ordering his wings, diſorders ſome of his feathers in bruſing them againſt deaths head, Venus having intelligence that her ſon had got ſuch a chamber-fellow, to prevent miſtakings brings in the light of nature; Cupid whoſe feathers were not right, reaches and ſtretches out his wings, flutters, and claps them too and againe, and blowes out the candle: goe then as you are, ſaid Venus to Cu • id, Time ſaid the like to Death; both never reſted from journying till they came to my very doore, being come there, they both ſtrove for priority; Death ſaid, he ſcorn'd to give place to Cupid, becauſe he was but a boy; and the boy anſwered him as prettily againe, that he ſcorn'd to be beholding to him, and ſo flew in at the window: By this unfortunate miſtake, death who intended to ſtrike me, ſlew my daughter; and Cupid that would have play'd his part with Flora, over-acts his part with me: Here I have it, here I burne. I cannot ſay I ſwim in love, but I am over head and eares: But where ſhall I entertaine my Miſtris? I will have all this great City contriv▪d into one houſe, and the inhabitants ſhall leave being Citizens, and become officers;
its no matter for their liberties, ſo they be my ſervants, for that ſhal be their greateſt freedom. Ile have my houſe well furniſh'd with Taxes and Rates, and hung about with Sequeſtrations: For I muſt tell you, Sirs, I am become immortall, and will make ye all Kings; but ye muſt be rul'd by me, for ye ſhall ſee me flye in the ayre, walke upon the water, run through the fire, hang up the terreſtiall globe, upon one of the Celeſtiall poles, and it ſhall ſo hang by the ſecret invention, that all Summer long it ſhall ſwing towards the North, in Winter towards the Southerne clime: ſo that both Summers heat, and Winters cold ſhall be no more, but a ſweet temper all the yeare: nothing but Spring and Autome, pleaſure and profit, ſhall ye have. This is the golden age the Poets propheſied of. I tell you what, they never ſprinkled holy water over Veſuvias head; for if they had, it would have quenched its flames. To morrow I am to be married to Don Olympia. I bid you to my wedding. The triple Crowne's mine owne already; and me-thinks I heare the keys jingling in my pocket.—
1. Peo. He talks extravagantly.
2. Peo. Hee's wild me-thinks.
3. Peo. Stark mad.

sp.speaker: Bakers.
sp.p: Come downe.

sp.speaker: Butchers.
sp.p: Come downe I ſay.

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Come downe, why ſo I will come downe; Time is to loſe his fore-top, and Cupid is to be whipt; what would you have?

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: Your head:

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Take it.
sp.stage: He thruſts out his head, and they cut off a falſe head made of a bladder fill'd with bloud. Exeunt with his body.

div.head: SCENA V.
div.p: A Solemne funerall of Maſſ. in warlike manner paſſes over the Stage, Maſſ. open fac'd after the manner of the Italians lyes carri▪d upon a Beere, he makes croſſes, bleſſing the people with a counterf • it right hand, that is directed by a Fryer who ſtands under the Beer; the people cry out wonderfull, wonderfull, he bleſses us, he was a Saint, and dyed our Martyr; this was but a trick of the royall party, who ſhall know that there are a hundred Maſſenelloes more in Naples.
div.stage: Enter the funerall of Flora meeting them; the Prince chieſe mourner, the prophetick Hermite on his right hand, with all his friends, and attendants.
Maior ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: HEre they are, here they be, let's fall upon them, while we may, we have loſt too many ſuch opportunities; make ready my Maſters.

sp.speaker: Pr. advances.
sp.p: Gentlemen, what doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: We meane to let you know, what tis to murther

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.p: whoſe ſelfe alone was worth you all; 'twas but their hands that acted what your heads contriv'd, for which you ſhall ſoon ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Let but theſe your executioners go with me to the grave, that I may but lay, my deareſt Saint to reſt in peace, and then do what you pleaſe; and for mine own part, if I aske you life, let me not live; for as her death did give my ſorrows life, ſo my death will eaſe my paine, and end my ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: He bleſſes us againe: O holy Saint!

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: This was a Saint, not call'd a Saint, but as you ſee confirmed by wonder, and the hand of miracle.

sp.speaker: Hermit.
sp.p: By the hand of an impoſtor. If you will be undeceived, you may look under the Beere, and you ſhall finde a Jugler playing the Hocus Pocus with you.
sp.stage: He holds up the cloath and ſhewes the people a Fryer underneath with his juggling inſtruments, and Maſſenelloes falſe arme diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: If neither the lawes of God, nor the lawes of nature, or the Land, nor the rule of reaſon, yet let experience beare ſome ſway, let palpable demonſtrations worke upon you, what do you doe with eyes and eares, if you will not believe their intelligence? do you not ſee your ſelves couſened? Do you not ſee your ſelves puppet plaid into a new war? O return therfore to your old obedience, & your hearts cannot deſire more than your Prince will give you, what is paſt ſhall be forgotten, and forgiven, 'tis the falſe Clergy (my deare Citizens) who have contributed the fuel, laid it together, ſet live coales under it, and then have been the bellowes to all thoſe combuſtions, as if all miſcheifes had been but ſo many exaltations of their braines, ſet on fire by the continuall motions and agitations of their tongues, witneſſe this incendiary, O returne, returne! unto your Prince, whoſe armes were alwayes open to receive you into his boſome, whenſoever you ſhould make it, though but your laſt refuge.
sp.stage: The people cry a King, a King, a King, fall upon the Fryer, and beat him to death, throw down the body of Maſſenello, ſaying, his louſie duſt ſhal not be carried into the ſepulchers of Kings.

sp.speaker: V. Roy
sp.p: Wel then good people, ſince 'tis ſo with you, you and the children that are yet unborne ſhall have juſtcauſe to ſay this was a happy day, and ye ſhal ſoon find the difference between a ſuppoſitious and a natural parent: Al things ſhall be ſo forgot as if they had not been, And perchance
We'le laugh our follies out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Omnes,

p.hi: Vita il Re di Spaine, vita, vita, vita.

sp.stage: Exeunt Omnes ſhouldring and affronting the Mayor.
Enter a Herauld at armes with Trumpetors on each ſide of him.
sp.p: To all perſons of what degrees and qualities ſoever, is proclaimed a generall pardon by the moſt—
sp.stage: [Maſſenello r • vives, and ſtarts up, ſpeakes.]

sp.speaker: Maſſ.
sp.p: Ha, whoſe that, that talkes of a general pardon? the word revives me, and hath brought me my ſoul again, and hath faſtened once more unto this clog.
Your pardon, and Ile ſpeake the Epilogue.

lg.l: LEt Kings beware how they provoke
Their Subjects with too hard a Yoke,
For when all's done, it will not doe,
You ſee they breake the Yoke in two:
Let Subjects no rebellion move
On ſuch pretences leaſt it prove,
As ſad a thing, (which God forbid)
And fatall as to us it did.
Much blood ſpilt, great battails won,
Our treaſure ſpent, and nothing done.
Leaſt fooles the wiſe ones do deride,
Gentles foot it, beggars ride,
Lazy Lubbers get the riches,
Women preach and weare the britches,
Leſt vengeance fall as did on me
Vndone; and my poſterity,
Help'd and ſuccour'd from all parts
Supported by the peoples hearts.
Riches, honours made me glad:
Pride and glory made me mad,
Madneſſe made me do ſuch things
The people wiſh'd they had their Kings
The King aſſures them acts of grace,
Here they leave me in the place.
And like Acteon ('t may be ſe'd)
By my owne dogges I'me worried.
Fond men be rul'd, play not with Kings,
With Lyons clawes, nor Serpents ſtings.
For Rebellion, and treaſon;
Rots your name, and outs your reaſon,
Could all the traytors that are dead,
But riſe—they'd ſay—as I have ſed.
